0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Direct injection of sperm into cytoplasm of the oocyte - In vitro fertilization: (Follistim(R) AQ) initial, 150 to 225 international units SUBQ/IM daily for at least 4 days; adjust dose based on ovarian response to a MAX of 600 international units/day and continue for 6 to 12 days; administer hCG 5000 to 10,000 units once follicular development is evident
  • Direct injection of sperm into cytoplasm of the oocyte - In vitro fertilization: (Follistim(R) AQ Cartridge) initial, 200 international units SUBQ daily for at least 7 days; adjust dose based on ovarian response to a MAX of 500 international units/day and continue for 7 to 12 days; administer hCG 5000 to 10,000 units once follicular development is evident
  • Male hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, Primary and secondary, not associated with primary testicular failure - Spermatogenesis induction: (Follistim(R) AQ, Follistim(R) AQ Cartridge) 450 international units total weekly dose SUBQ divided as 225 international units twice weekly, or 150 international units 3 times weekly for 3 to 4 months with hCG at dosage used to normalize testosterone levels; pretreatment with hCG 1500 international units twice weekly to normalize testosterone levels, may increase to hCG 3000 international units twice weekly after 8 weeks if testosterone levels have not normalized
  • Ovulation induction, In anovulatory women with functional infertility: (Follistim(R) AQ) initial, 75 international units SUBQ/IM daily for at least the first 7 days; may increase dose in 25 or 50 international unit increments at weekly intervals until adequate response; MAX 300 international units/day; administer hCG 5000 to 10,000 units once follicular development is evident and/or serum estradiol levels are adequate
  • Ovulation induction, In anovulatory women with functional infertility: (Follistim(R) AQ Cartridge) initial, 50 international units SUBQ daily for at least the first 7 days; may increase dose in 25 or 50 international unit increments at weekly intervals until adequate response; MAX 250 international units/day; administer hCG 5000 to 10,000 units once follicular development is evident and/or serum estradiol levels are adequate

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: safety and effectiveness have not been established in pediatric patients

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Direct injection of sperm into cytoplasm of the oocyte - In vitro fertilization
  • Male hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, Primary and secondary, not associated with primary testicular failure - Spermatogenesis induction
  • Ovulation induction, In anovulatory women with functional infertility

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• abnormal vaginal bleeding of undetermined origin
  • high circulating follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) level indicating primary ovarian failure
  • hypersensitivity to recombinant human follicle stimulating hormone (hFSH) products
  • hypersensitivity to streptomycin or neomycin products; may contain trace amounts of these antibiotics
  • ovarian cysts or enlargement not due to polycystic ovary syndrome
  • pregnancy
  • tumor of the ovary, breast, or uterus, hypothalamus, or pituitary gland
  • uncontrolled non-gonadal endocrinopathies, including thyroid, adrenal, and pituitary disorders

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• multifetal gestation and births have been reported
  • ovarian enlargement, abnormal, uncomplicated; may occur; monitoring recommended
  • Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS) has been reported; withhold hCG if OHSS occurs prior to hCG administration; acute-, chronic-, and resolution-phase management recommended, discontinue treatment with serious cases; monitoring recommended
  • ovarian neoplasms, benign and malignant; have been reported in women receiving multiple ovarian induction therapies
  • ovarian torsion has been reported
  • pulmonary complications, including atelectasis and acute respiratory distress syndrome; have been reported
  • thromboembolic reactions, including venous thrombophlebitis, pulmonary embolism, pulmonary infarction, arterial occlusion, cerebrovascular accident, myocardial infarction, and death, with and without concomitant ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome; have been reported
  • thromboembolic risk factors, including personal and family history, severe obesity, and thrombophilia; increased risk of thromboembolic reactions

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Acne (6.7%), Injection site pain (IM, 31%; subQ, 6.7% to 28%), Injection site reaction (women, 2% or greater; men, 6.7%), Rash (women, 2% or greater; men, 3.3%)
  • Endocrine metabolic:Gynecomastia (3.3%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal discomfort (2.9%), Abdominal pain (2.2% to 2.9%), Lower abdominal pain (2.9%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (women, 2% or greater; men 6.7%)
  • Reproductive:Cyst of ovary (2.9%)
  • Other:Mature cystic teratoma (3.3%)
Serious
  • Hematologic:Cerebrovascular accident, Occlusion of artery, Thromboembolic disorder, Thrombophlebitis
  • Reproductive:Ectopic pregnancy, Miscarriage, Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (6.4% to 7.6%), Torsion of ovary
  • Respiratory:Acute respiratory distress syndrome, Atelectasis, Pulmonary embolism, Pulmonary infarction

2.title: Class
2.mono:
• Female Reproductive Agent
  • Human Follicle Stimulating Hormone
  • Human Follicle Stimulating Hormone Combination

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) is secreted by the anterior pituitary, which influences the processes of gonadal germ cell differentiation and development in both sexes. Follitropin beta is a recombinant FSH. In females, follitropin beta stimulates follicular growth, maturation, and gonadal steroid production. Follitropin beta stimulates ovarian follicular growth in women who do not have primary ovarian failure. When follicular development has been achieved after treatment with follitropin beta, human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) must be administered to these women in order to effect the final phase of follicle maturation. In males, FSH (the active component of follistim beta) is the pituitary hormone responsible for spermatogenesis. Follitropin beta, therefore, stimulates spermatogenesis in men with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism when given with hCG.

3.title: Excretion
3.mono: Total body clearance: 0.013 to 0.014 L/hr/kg (Japanese and European women, respectively)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
General Information
  • allow drug to reach room temperature before injecting to avoid discomfort
  • Follistim(R) AQ can be given as an IM or subQ injection
  • Follistim(R) AQ Cartridge with pen injector can only be given subQ

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• ovulation induction: serum estradiol levels and ultrasound; at weekly intervals to determine follicle maturation, an adequate ovarian response, and the need for continued treatment
  • assisted reproductive technology: serum estradiol levels and ultrasound; following the first 4 days of treatment, at an individualized frequency to determine follicle maturation, an adequate ovarian response, and the need for continued treatment
  • ovulation induction and assisted reproductive technology: increases in urinary or serum luteinizing hormone and serum progesterone, sonographic evidence of collapsed follicle, fluid in the cul-de-sac, and corpus luteum formation indicates ovulation
  • ovulation induction and assisted reproductive technology: HCG level to confirm intrauterine pregnancy and rule out ectopic pregnancy
  • induction of spermatogenesis: serum testosterone levels following human chorionic gonadotropin administration and analysis of semen for evidence of spermatogenesis; an increase in sperm density may indicate efficacy
  • serum estradiol levels; excessive ovarian stimulation
  • symptoms of excessive ovarian syndrome every other day during treatment and for 2 weeks following treatment with follitropin beta
  • ultrasound; to detect ectopic pregnancy, to detect multifetal gestations, to reduce the risk of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome and abnormal ovarian enlargement

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
Follistim AQ
  • Injection Solution: 75 IU/0.5 ML, 150 IU/0.5 ML
  • Subcutaneous Solution: 300 IU/0.36 ML, 600 IU/0.72 ML, 900 IU/1.08 ML

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Inform female patients that this drug may cause multiple births.
  • Inform female patients this drug may cause headache, injection site reaction, ovarian cysts, and abdominal pain and discomfort.
  • Inform male patients this drug may cause headache, injection site pain or reactions, breast enlargement, acne, and rash.
  • Advise female patient to report signs/symptoms of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (abdominal bloating/distension, lower abdominal pain, severe pelvic pain, dyspnea, decreased urination) during and 2 weeks posttreatment.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of pulmonary or vascular problems such as thromboembolic disorder, acute respiratory distress syndrome, or atelectasis.
  • If self-administered, teach patient proper technique and placement of injections.
  • Advise patient to rotate injection sites.
  • Advise patient if a dose is missed, it should not be doubled at the next administration and inform their healthcare provider regarding further dosing instructions.
